Overload.descr: Returns the value as an absolute number (if it is negative, it will be changed to a positive).
Returns the arccosine of the angle. acos(cos(x)) = x, if x is between 0 and 180.
Returns the sum of two values.
Adds the path to use when reading images or sounds from an archive file. Returns true if the archive was successfully read, false otherwise.
Adds the given value to the graze count.
Adds the given value to the point count.
Registers the given key id to the replay file. This key id should be one that you have already registered with AddVirtualKey.
Adds the given value to the score.

Registers the given virtual key with the given key. You may map any number of virtual keys to a single key, but virtual keys may only be mapped to a single key. For an example, if you were to use AddVirtualKey(VK_SHOT, KEY_UP, KEY_INVALID);, whenever you press the up arrow key, the virtual shot key will be pressed. Take note that you will not be able to move up. To fix this, you add AddVirtualKey(VK_UP, KEY_UP, KEY_INVALID);. You will now shoot and move up at the same time. However, if you were to add AddVirtualKey(VK_UP, KEY_LEFT, KEY_INVALID); with the above two examples, you will not move up when you press up, because VK_UP has been remapped to KEY_LEFT.
Returns the arcsine of the value. asin(sin(x)) = x, if x is between -90 and 90.
Returns the arctangent of the value. atan(tan(x)) = x, if x is between -90 and 90.

Returns the arctangent of y/x, which is the angle from (0, 0) to (x, y). The angle will be in the range -180 < a <= 180, where a is the returned value. Useful for getting the angle from one point to another point. For example, the angle from the boss to the player is atan2(player y - boss y, player x - boss x).
Takes the contents of an array and converts it into an integer.
Takes the contents of an array and converts it into a real number.
Full border
No border
Shadow at the bottom right of the text
If the conditions to use a spell card are met, uses the spell card.
Cancels any items that were currently moving to the player for collection.
Returns the value rounded up to the next integer.
Removes all of the common data in the specified area.
Removes all of the common data in the default common data area.
Clears invalid render priority. (unsure)
Ends the package script.
Stops the specified script. Until this function is called, the script will continue to run.
Ends the current scene (returns to script selection screen).
UTF16 BE
UTF16 LE
Makes all items fly towards the player.
Makes all items of the specified type fly toward the player.
Makes all items within the circle fly toward the player.
Copies the common data in the source area to the destination area. If the source common data area is invalid, nothing will happen.
Returns the cosine of the angle. Cosine is a value between -1 and 1 that corresponds to the x-value in a coordinate plane.
Creates a common data area to organize common data together. A common data area "" (empty string) has been created by default, which is also used by the SetCommonData series.

Creates a laser that will move in the angle and speed defined, but can be altered with ObjMove_SetAngularVelocity to create a curving laser. his function is heavy to process, so having many of them on-screen is not recommended.
Creates an item at the specified point. The types ending in "_S" will create a smaller version of the specified item. "scoring" is the value the spawned item will add to your score.
Creates an item at the specified point and sets how quickly it will move towards the specified coordinates before slowly falling down. "scoring" is the value the spawned item will add to your score.
Creates a user-defined item associated with the specified ID at the specified point. "scoring" is the value the spawned item will add to your score.

Creates a user-defined item associated with the specified ID at the specified point and sets how quickly it will move towards the specified coordinates before slowly falling down. "scoring" is the value the spawned item will add to your score.

Creates a laser that act like a bullet and will move in the angle and speed defined, but can be defined with a size. This could also be used to create larger bullets. Graphic is the image the laser will have, while delay is the time in frames that the laser will appear. During it's delay, there will be a cloud that appears where the bullet will spawn.
The player fires the specified shot.

Creates a basic bullet that will move in the angle and speed defined. Graphic is the image the bullet will have, while delay is the time in frames that the bullet will appear. During it's delay, there will be a cloud that appears where the bullet will spawn. Note that the function will return a void value in a player script if the player is unable to shoot.

Creates a basic bullet that will move in the angle, speed, acceleration and max speed defined. Graphic is the image the bullet will have, while delay is the time in frames that the bullet will appear. During it's delay, there will be a cloud that appears where the bullet will spawn. The number defined for acceleration will be applied to the bullet per frame, so this will usually have low numbers such as 0.1. Negative values may be used, however, having a negative value on acceleration but a positive number on max speed (or vice versa) will result in the bullet spawning at max speed. Note that the function will return a void value in a player script if the player is unable to shoot.

Creates a basic bullet that will move in x and y speeds defined. Graphic is the image the bullet will have, while delay is the time in frames that the bullet will appear. During it's delay, there will be a cloud that appears where the bullet will spawn. Note that the function will return a void value in a player script if the player is unable to shoot.

Creates a basic bullet that will move in the angle, speed, x and y accelerations and max/min speeds defined. Graphic is the image the bullet will have, while delay is the time in frames that the bullet will appear. During it's delay, there will be a cloud that appears where the bullet will spawn. The number defined for acceleration will be applied to the bullet per frame, so this will usually have low numbers such as 0.1. Negative values may be used, however, having a negative value on acceleration but a positive number on max speed (or vice versa) will result in the bullet spawning at max speed. Note that the function will return a void value in a player script if the player is unable to shoot.

Creates a bullet that will spawn on the coordinates of the given object id. Graphic is the image the bullet will have, while delay is the time in frames that the bullet will appear. During it's delay, there will be a cloud that appears where the bullet will spawn. Note that the function will return a void value in a player script if the player is unable to shoot.

Creates a basic bullet that will spawn on the coordinates of the given object id and will move in x and y speeds defined. Graphic is the image the bullet will have, while delay is the time in frames that the bullet will appear. During it's delay, there will be a cloud that appears where the bullet will spawn. Note that the function will return a void value in a player script if the player is unable to shoot.

Creates a laser mounted on a position. The "deleteTime" argument determines how many frames until the laser disappears. Graphic is the image the laser will have. Delay will spawn a very thin laser that has no collision in order to give the player a warning. Having no delay while using this laser is not advisable, as they spawn at full size the moment the delay is over.
Removes the common data mapping with the specified key in the specified area.
Removes the common data mapping with the specified key.

Deletes all bullets. ALL will clear all bullets and lasers, SHOT will clear only bullets, and CHILD will clear bullets and lasers fired from the currently running script (e.g. a stage script that spawns enemies, putting CHILD in one of the enemy's script will clear only that enemy's bullets). The second type determines how the bullet will be deleted. IMMEDIATE will immediately delete the bullets, FADE will slowly fade the bullets (note, they will still be visible while fading out, but they will not have any collision), and ITEM will turn the bullets into points that will immediately be collected to the player.
Same as DeleteShotAll, except it will only clear bullets in a defined circle.
Returns the quotient of two values.

Removes the element at the given index from an array. Returns the given array, with the element at the given index removed
Event will fade out the shot
Event will delete the shot immediately
Notification for when a bullet is itemized, and will only be called in an item script. GetEventArgument(1) will return the bullet's coordinates (real array, [x, y]).
Notification for the end of 1 step of the boss (The end of 1 Single script). This will notify all active scripts.
Notification for when a spellcard is captured, and will notify all active scripts.
Notification for when an item is collected, and will only be called in a player script. GetEventArgument(0) is used to check what item was collected.
Notification for when the player is grazing, and will only be called in a player script. This is used for producing the grazing effect and sfx.
Notification when [the player] shot down, and will only be called in a player script. This is used for producing the explosion effects and sfx.

Notification for when the game is paused, and will notify all active scripts. This event is used to stop the playing of audio. In this event, do not generate bullets, enemies, or use random numbers. Replays will be desyncronized if you do so.

Notification for when the game is unpaused, and will notify all active scripts. This event is used to resume the playing of audio. In this event, do not generate bullets, enemies, or use random numbers. Replays will be desyncronized if you do so.
Notification for when the player is revived, and will notify all active scripts.
Notification when the player is shot down, and will notify all active scripts.
Notification for when a bomb is used, and will notify all active scripts.

Requests if the spell card is a survival spell card, and will only be called in a boss script. It is necessary to return a boolean value using SetScriptResult. Ignoring this will cause the spell to not be a survival spell.

Requests if the spell card is a last spell, and will only be called in a boss script. It is necessary to return a boolean value using SetScriptResult. Ignoring this will cause the spell to not be a last spell.
Requests for the boss's life, and will only be called in a boss script. It is necessary to return a real value using SetScriptResult. Ignoring the request will produce an error.

Requests if a bomb is possible, and will only be called in a player script. It is necessary to return a boolean value using SetScriptResult. Return true if a bomb may be used. If the request is ignored, then an error will be produced.

This will request for the spell card score, and will only be called in a boss script. It is necessary to return a boolean value using SetScriptResult. Ignoring this will set the spell card score to 0 points.
Requests for the boss timer, and will only be called in a boss script. It is necessary to return a real value using SetScriptResult. Ignoring this will cause the boss to have no time limit.
Notification for the start of an enemy spell card, and will notify all active scripts.
Notification for the start of 1 step of the boss (The start of 1 Single script). This will notify all active scripts.
Notification for when an enemy spell is timed out, and will notify all active scripts.
Called only once at the end of a stage. Calling ends the stage processing. Defines the end point of replays
Returns the value rounded down to the next integer.
Returns the z rotation angle of the camera.
Returns the zoom ratio of the camera.
Returns the x zoom ratio of the camera.
Returns the y zoom ratio of the camera.
Returns the x-coordinate of the camera.
Returns the y-coordinate of the camera.
Returns the 2D coordinates of the given 3D coordinates. The array is returned as [X, Y].
Gets the ID of every enemy present on the screen, and returns them in an array.
Gets the the position of all enemies for which collision detection is true (currently intersecting), and returns it in a 2-dimension array ([index][<x-coordinate, y-coordinate>]).
Gets the angle from the object with specified ID to the player.
Returns the value associated with the given key in the specified area in common data. Returns the default value if no value had been stored to it previously.
Returns the azimuth angle from the focus point to the camera.
Returns the elevation angle from the focus point to the camera.
Returns the highest render priority the 2D camera can affect (0-100) (default is 79)
Returns the x-coordinate of the focus point.
Returns the y-coordinate of the focus point.
Returns the z-coordinate of the focus point.
Returns the vertical Pitch angle of the camera.
Returns the distance from the focus point to the camera.
Returns the rotational Roll angle of the camera.
Returns the x-coordinate of the camera.
Returns the y-coordinate of the camera.
Returns the horizontal Yaw angle of the camera.
Returns the z-coordinate of the camera.
Returns the value associated with the given key in common data. Returns the default value if no value had been stored to it previously.
Returns an array of all common data area names.
Returns an array of the keys in the specified area.

Returns a string containing the current date and time. For example, if the current date is 2012/09/16 12:34:56, then "20120916123456" will be returned.If you wanted to convert it to a number, you may use the atoifunction; for example, let year = atoi(GetCurrentDateTimeS[0..4]);
Returns the current FPS.
Returns the directory of the file in which this function was called.
Returns an array of the directories available within the directory of the specified path.
Gets the ID of the boss present on the screen, and returns it in an array.
Gets the boss scene object ID. When not in a boss scene, returns ID_INVALID.
Gets the enemy intersection position around given position, and returns a 2D array ([index][<x-coordinate, y-coordinate>]). The first value (index 0) corresponds to the nearest position.

Gets all collision detection positions of the specified enemy, and returns a 2D array ([index][<x-coordinate, y-coordinate>]). The first value (index 0) corresponds to the nearest position from the enemy (unsure).

Gets all collision detection positions of the specified enemy, and returns a 2D array ([index][<x-coordinate, y-coordinate>]). The first value (index 0) corresponds to the nearest position from the specified position.
Returns the argument of the event currently triggered in @Event. Can be an arbitrary value.
Returns the event type currently triggered in @Event.
Returns the directory of the specified file path. Specifically, returns the input string up to the rightmost forward slash, with backslashes removed.
Returns a list of files in the folder of the specified file path (or folder path).
Returns the number of player scripts available in the /script/player/folder.
Returns various information about the player script. Index of the player script must be less than GetFreePlayerScriptCount.
Returns the current amount of graze.
Gets the Object ID of all enemies with a registered hitbox to player shots (via ObjEnemy_SetIntersectionCircleToShot()).
Returns the render priority for items (0-100) (default is 60).
Returns the given key id's current state.
Loads a list of the player scripts available in the /script/player/folder.
Returns the directory of the currently running package script.
Returns the directory of the current stage of the script running.
Returns the path of the current stage of the script running.
Returns the directory containing the running th_dnh.exe file.

Returns the amount of change that has occurred to the mouse's Z axis. The Z axis is normally the middle mouse wheel. If there is no mouse wheel, the value will be 0. The value returned will be negative if the wheel was moved back, and positive if the wheel moved forward.
Returns the given mouse button's current state.

Returns the mouse's X coordinate. The origin for the mouse coordinates is the upper left of the Danmakufu window (0, 0). Mouse coordinates will be properly adjusted according to the resizing of Danmakufu's window.

Returns the mouse's Y coordinate. The origin for the mouse coordinates is the upper left of the Danmakufu window (0, 0). Mouse coordinates will be properly adjusted according to the resizing of Danmakufu's window.
Returns the 2D coordinates of a 3D object. The array is returned as [X, Y].
Returns the distance between the two objects. If one of the objects' ID is invalid, -1 will be returned.
Returns the script's own ID during execution.
Returns a number with the amount of time that has been elapsed since the start of the package script. The value is in milliseconds.
Gets the player's clip in an array [left, top, right, bottom].
Returns the amount of frames that the player will spend in the down state.
Returns the system ID of the player script. This value is defined inside the player script in the #ID header.
Gets the amount of frames the player is invincible.
Gets the player's life points.
Gets player object ID.
Gets the amount of power points.
Gets the amount of frames the player can counter bomb.
Returns the render priority for the player (0-100) (default is 30).
Returns the replay ID of the player. This value is defined inside the player script in the #ReplayName header.
Returns the player's script ID. This function returns the same value as GetOwnScriptID when used inside the player script.
Gets the player's speed in an array [unfocused, focused].
Gets the amount of bombs remaining.
Gets the player state.
Gets the x-coordinate of the player.
Gets the y-coordinate of the player.
Returns the current amount of point items collected (default is the blue "ten" item).
Returns the FPS of the replay at the current time. Note that this value refreshes as a much slower rate than GetCurrentFps.
Returns the replay information requested. The replay index must be less than GetValidReplayIndices.
Acquires the render target name reserved at Danmakufu's startup. (unsure) The texture acquired by this function necessarily exists.
Returns the current score.
Returns the Height of Danmakufu's drawing space.
Returns the width of Danmakufu's drawing space.
Returns the value of the specified argument, previously set by SetScriptArgumentbefore the script was started.
Returns the number of arguments set by SetScriptArgumentbefore the script was started.
Returns const script type if infoType = INFO_SCRIPT_TYPE. Returns string for other info types.
Returns an array of available (selectable at selection screen) scripts of the specified type within the directory of the specified path.
Returns the event result from SetScriptResult. Can be an arbitrary value.
Returns the number of bullets that exist from the given target.

Returns information depending on the information requested. INFO_TYPE: Returns real array: [left, top, right, bottom]. INFO_DELAY_COLOR: Returns real array: [red, green, blue]. INFO_BLEND: Returns real (BLEND_ALPHA, BLEND_ADD_RGB, or BLEND_ADD_ARGB). INFO_COLLISION: Radius of collision detection. INFO_COLLISION_LIST: Returns real two-dimensional array: [radius, x, y]
Returns the object IDs of the bullets inside the given circle in an array. Inside the player script, it will only return enemy bullet IDs, and vice versa.
Returns the IDs of the bullets inside the given circle and corresponding to the target in an array.
Returns the render priority for shots (0-100) (default is 50).
Retrieves the ID of the spell manage object. It is necessary to delete this object using ObjDelete once the spell is over.
Returns the reason the stage was finished.
Can be used to return status information about the currently running stage.
Returns a number with the amount of time that has been elapsed since the start of the main script. The value is in milliseconds.
Returns the height of the STG frame.
Returns the leftmost value of the STG frame.
Returns the highest render priority for the STG frame (0-100) (default is 80).
Returns the lowest render priority for the STG frame (0-100) (default is 20).
Returns the topmost value of the STG frame.
Returns the width of the STG frame.
Returns the height (real) of the specified image file.
Returns the width (real) of the specified image file.

Specifically to be used by menu scripts such as the pause script. This can be used to create a texture of the previous frame just before the game is paused. This allows for effects to be applied such as fading to a blur.
Loads a list of indices for the current script's available replays.
Returns the state of the specified virtual key.
Returns the amount of attacks of the enemy for the active step.
Returns an array containing the proportion (0-1) of each attacks's amount of life in the active step.
Returns the total remaining life for the active step.
Returns the initial life of the enemy for the active step.
Blending type. Returns real. can be BLEND_ALPHA, BLEND_ADD_RGB, or BLEND_ADD_ARGB
Radius of collision detection. Returns real,
List of collision hitbox radii and coordinates. Returns real two-dimensional array: [radius, x, y]
Returns the current life of the enemy in the current attack.
Returns the maximum life of the enemy in the current attack.
Damage rate percentage of normal player shots set by ObjEnemy_SetDamageRate (real: 1-100)
Damage rate percentage of player bombs set by ObjEnemy_SetDamageRate (real: 1-100)
Delay color RGB list. Returns real array: [red, green, blue]
Returns true in the case of a survival spell.
Returns true if the Last Spell is active.
Returns true when the last spell is active.
Returns true if a spell card is active.
Returns the score value of the item object (real).
Life points of the enemy (real)
Returns the original timer value in frames (returns -1 if unlimited).
Returns the amount of times the player died during the spell.
Returns the amount of times the player bombed during the spell.
Coordinate rect list. Returns real array: [left, top, right, bottom]
Returns the number of steps remaining in the active boss scene.
Returns the script #ID (char)
Returns the script #Image (char)
Returns the script path (char)
Returns the script #ReplayName (char)
Returns the script #Text (char)
Returns the script #Title (char)
Returns the script type (TYPE_SCRIPT_* constant)
Amount of times the enemy was hit by player bullets in the previous frame
Returns the score of the spell card.
Returns the timer value in seconds.
Returns the timer value in frames (returns -1 if unlimited).
Called only once before the start of a stage. Calling performs the initial processing for the stage.

Loads the given font, which can be used with ObjText_SetFontType, allowing for usage of fonts that are not standard to Windows. Returns true if successful. Note, anything other than a Shift-JIS font will not be displayed properly if Danmakufu is run with AppLocale (before ph3 [.1 pre2]).
Returns the value as a string, omits any decimal places.
Returns whether the specified script has been stopped. Returns true if the script is not running.
Returns whether the specified common data area exists.
Checks if the given line is colliding with the given circle. Returns true if there is a collision; if there is no collision, it returns false.

Checks if the given objects are colliding with each other. Returns true if there is a collision; if there is no collision, it returns false. This function is currently only available on bullet and laser objects.
Returns true if the player can use normal shots.
Returns true if the player can use bombs. The returned value may differ from a previously set SetForbidPlayerSpell. For instance, it is forced to false during a LastSpell.
Checks your whether or not your GPU supports the specified pixel shader version. Returns true if supported. Example: IsPixelShaderSupported(3,0); //checks for Pixel Shader version 3.0
Returns true if the player is counter bombing.
Returns true if the player is currently using a bomb (not only the button press).
Returns true if a replay is playing, false otherwise.
Returns true or false depending on the index chosen is valid to be used in GetReplayInfo.
Life item
Life part
Pops upward, then drops down
Automatically flies towards the player
Point item
Small point item
Power up item
Small power up item
Bomb item
Small bomb item
User defined item
Converts an integer value to an array form, but leaves out decimal places.
Number Pad +
Number Pad .
Number Pad /
Down Arrow Key
The key is not pressed
The key is being held
Invalid key
Left Ctrl key
Left Arrow Key
Left Shift
Number Pad *
Number Pad =
The key has been released
The key has been pressed
Right Ctrl key
Right Arrow Key
Right Shift
Number Pad -
Up Arrow Key
Gets the size of an array
Loads everything in the specified common data area from the saved data file. Returns true if successful and false if the operation failed.
Loads everything in the specified common data area from the saved data file at the specified path. Returns true if successful and false if the operation failed.
Loads the specified common data area from the replay file. Returns true if successful and false if the operation failed. If this function is called during gameplay, Danmakufu will present an error.
Loads specified shot image file. missing explanation about calling the function several times (?) Files with the same name can only be loaded once.

Loads the specified item data. Can be called any amount of times, but currently existing IDs will be replaced by new ones of the same value. You may not use the same file twice in this function; to do so, see ReloadItemData.
Loads the shot data image file. If called several times, loads each file in succession. A file cannot be loaded multiple times in a row.
Loads a list of the available replays for the current script.
Loads and compiles the specified script, and returns its script ID. Also calls @Loading and initializes global variables.
Loads and compiles the specified script in a different thread, and returns its script ID. Also calls @Loading and initializes global variables.
Loads specified sound file.
Loads specified image file as a texture.

Loads specified image file as a texture in a separate thread. Using this function inside @Loading is the same as using LoadTexture. When using large images, the script will freeze until the image has finished loading.
Returns the natural (base e) logarithmof the value.
Returns the common (base 10) logarithmof the value.
Returns the greater of the two values.
Returns the lesser of the two values.

Returns a modulus of the first value. Modulus provides the remainder of the division (7 modulo 5 would be 2). Note: unlike remainder, modc returns a value with the same sign as the dividend: modc(-7, 4) equals -3 and modc(7, -4) equals 3.
Left Mouse Button
Middle Mouse Button
RightMouse Button
Returns the product of two values.
Calls the @Event of the script with the specified ID, triggering the specified event. The event type may use a value greater than EV_USER.
Calls the @Event of all scripts, triggering the specified event. The event type may use a value greater than EV_USER.
Curved laser
Deletes specified object.
Deletes the key-value pair previously set by Obj_SetValue.
A binary file
A text file
Returns the object's render priority as a ratio (0.0-1.0).
Returns the object's render priority as an integer (0-100).
Retrieves the type of object.

Returns the value associated with the given key for the given object, previously set by Obj_SetValue. Warning: If the key-value pair does not exist or was deleted, attempting to access it will crash the program.
Returns the value associated with the given key for the given object, previously set by Obj_SetValue. If the key-value pair doesn't exist, the default value is returned instead.
Returns true if the specified object has been deleted.
Checks whether the object has a key-value pair for the given key and returns true if it does.
Returns true if the specified object is visible.
Loose laser
Primitive (triangle) in the 2D space
Primitive (triangle) in the 3D space
Sets the object's render priority as a ratio (0.0-1.0).
Sets the object's render priority in the range 0-100 (integer).
For the given object, maps the given key to the given value. The value can be returned by using Obj_GetValue with the corresponding key.
Sets visibility of specified object. If visible is set to false, the object will not be drawn.
Generic bullet
Rectangle in the 2D space (usable by the ObjSprite2D_ functions)
Rectangle in the 3D space (usable by the ObjSprite3D_ functions)
List of rectangles in the 2D space (usable by the ObjSpriteList2D_ functions)
Straight laser

Returns the number of times the specified object intersected with other objects during the previous frame. For example, this can be used to determine how many player shots have collided with an enemy (similar to GetHitCountin v0.12m).
Returns an array of all enemy object IDs that the specified object is currently intersecting with.
Returns true if the specified object is currently intersecting with another object.
Sets the transparency reduction rate at the tip of the curved laser object. (0.0-1.0) Default is 1.0 (tip of laser is invisible).
Adds the specified amount of life points to the enemy's life.

Creates an Enemy object and returns its ID. In order to draw the enemy object and have it listed as an existing enemy, you have to register it using ObjEnemy_Regist. If you want to create a boss enemy object, you have to create a boss scene object first.
Returns information about enemy.
Makes the specified enemy object active.
Sets the damage rate of the player's attacks against the specified enemy. Setting to 0 will cause the enemy to take no damage, 100 is the default (100%) value. Values above 100 are possible.
Sets the enemy hitbox for player collision. Any collision with the circle will kill the character.
Sets the position and size of the enemy hitbox (any attack from the player touching the circle will damage the enemy).
Sets the amount of life points for the specified enemy object.
Adds the specified script to the boss scene at the specified phase.
Creates a Boss Scene object and returns its ID.

Returns information about boss scene. With regards to the "step" info types, step refers to the individual sections specified in the ObjEnemyBossScene_Addfunction's second argument. For each script (referred to as an attack here) you load into the step, you increase the step life count of that specific step by 1.

Compiles all the enemy scripts in the boss scene and initializes global variables. As the length of compile time cannot be guaranteed, initialize all global variables besides constants in @Initialize.
Starts the specified boss scene.
Sets the timer.
Starts the boss spell card.
Creates a file object.
Returns file size in bytes(?).
Opens a file for reading with the specified path and binds the specified file object to the opened file.
Opens a file for both reading and writing with the specified path and binds the specified file object to the opened file.
Saves a file previously opened with ObjFile_OpenNW. Must be called once after writing the data.
Reads a byte from the file and returns a Boolean value.
Reads a 1-byte integer from the file.
Reads a 8-byte floating point number from the file.
Reads a 4-byte floating-point number from the file.
Reads a 4-byte integer from the file.
Reads a 8-byte integer from the file.
Reads a 2-byte integer from the file.
Given a specified number of bytes to read, reads a string. Note: due to a bug, this function will never return any characters outside of Shift-JIS.
Sets Byte Order of file. Options are: ENDIAN_LITTLE: Little endian (default) ENDIAN_BIG: Big endian
Sets Character Code of file. Default is CODE_ACP.
Adds line to text file.
Returns number of lines in text file.
Returns line of text from text file. Line number starts from 1.
Returns information about item.
Sets whether the item will be pulled towards the player when the player moves past the point of auto-collection.
Sets the movement type of the item object. Defaults to ITEM_MOVE_DOWN.
Sets the ID of the item object, as defined in the item definition script.
Sets whether a score indicator will be displayed when the item object is collected. This is the score given as argument to the CreateItem() functions.
Returns the length of the laser object.
Specify the number of frames after a graze where graze is not counted. If you specify 0, the laser object can be grazed only once. The default value is 20 frames (3 graze/second).
Sets the collision width of the laser object. This can be set to be larger than the laser object's render width, so take caution.
Sets the portion of the laser object where there is no collision, in relation to the base and the tip of the laser. By default, the values are 10 (10%).
Sets the length of the laser object.
Sets the visible width of the laser object (not the same as the laser object's collision width).
Creates a 3D mesh object and returns its ID.
Loads a 3D mesh file. The file must be either .mqo (Metasequoia) or .elem (Elfreina) (both are Japanese softwares).
Sets the alpha value of the mesh (0-255).
Sets the animation of the mesh object. The animation frame of the specified animation name is drawn.
Sets the color of the mesh (0-255).
When set to true, allows the mesh to be positioned using 2D coordinates.
After the specified number of frames, changes the speed and angle of the object. NO_CHANGE can be used to preserve the original speed or angle.
After the specified number of frames, changes the speed, angle, acceleration, angular velocity, and maximum speed of the object. NO_CHANGE can be used to preserve the original speed or angle.

After the specified number of frames, changes the speed, angle, acceleration, angular velocity, and maximum speed of the object. Changes the bullet graphic. (Similar to SetShotDataA, but with acceleration and angular velocity swapped)

After the specified number of frames, changes the speed, angle, acceleration, angular velocity, maximum speed and graphic of the object. The angle parameter is relative to the angle from the object to the target. For example, if GetPlayerObjectID is used as the target, an angle of 0 will cause the object to aim for the player. (Replaces SetShotDirectionType)
After the specified number of frames, changes the x and y movement speeds of the object. NO_CHANGE can be used to preserve the original speeds.
After the specified number of frames, changes the x and y movement speeds of the object. Can change object x/y acceleration and x/y maximum speed. NO_CHANGE can also be used for these new parameters.

After the specified number of frames, changes the x and y movement speeds of the object. Can change object x/y acceleration and x/y maximum speed. Can also change the bullet graphic. (Replaces SetShotDataA_XY)
Returns the movement angle of the object.
Returns the movement speed of the object.
Returns the x coordinate of the object.
Returns the y coordinate of the object.
Sets the movement acceleration per frame for the object.
Sets the movement angle for the object.
Sets the change in movement angle per frame for the object.
Moves the object towards the given coordinates in the number of frames specified.
Moves the object towards the given coordinates at the speed specified.
Moves the object towards the given coordinates. It will slow down near the end of the movement based on the weight specified.
Sets the maximum/minimum speed which the object will approach using the ObjMove_SetAcceleration function.
Sets the x and y of the specified object.
Sets the movement speed per frame for the object.
Sets the x coordinate of the specified object.
Sets the y coordinate of the specified object.

Creates a hitbox of specified radius for collision detection of the player object. The graze area extends the specified radius around the hitbox (the true graze radius is the sum of the two). The hitbox will remain valid for every frame once created. Coordinates of hitbox center are set in relation to the player.
Creates a grazebox of specified radius for the player object. The grazebox will remain valid for every frame once created. Coordinates of hitbox center are set in relation to the player.
Deletes the hitbox of the player object.
Creates a Primitive object.
Returns the number of vertices the object contains.
Returns the position of the specified vertex in an array [x,y,z].
Sets the vertex layout for the object.
Sets the specified texture on the object. Loads the texture file if it has not already been loaded.
Sets the alpha value of the specified vertex (0-255).
Sets the color of the specified vertex (0-255).
Sets the number of vertices the object contains.
Sets the position of the specified vertex.

Sets the UV-coordinates for the specified vertex. The value for the coordinates must be in the range (0.0-1.0). For instance, if you want a vertex to be at the center-top of a 512*512 texture, you have to set x to 0.5 and y to 1.0. As it may be troublesome to convert pixels into a 0.0-1.0 value, ObjPrim_SetVertexUVT is recommended.
Sets the UV-coordinates for the specified vertex. You must set the object's texture using ObjPrim_SetTexture beforehand.
Returns the x-angle of the object.
Returns the y-angle of the object.
Returns the z-angle of the object.
Returns the blend type for the specified object.
Returns the x-scale of the object.
Returns the y-scale of the object.
Returns the z-scale of the object.
Returns the x-coordinate of the object.
Returns the y-coordinate of the object.
Returns the z-coordinate of the object.

Sets the alpha value of the object. A value of 0 will make the object invisible. A value of 255 will give the object full opacity. Alpha blend type must be used for this to work. To get a transparent render using additive blend, the color has to be set to black (0, 0, 0) using ObjRender_SetColor.
Sets the x-angle of the object.
Sets the x, y and z-angle of the object.
Sets the y-angle of the object.
Sets the z-angle of the object.
Sets the blend type for the specified object.
Sets the color of the object using RGB (0-255).
Sets the Hue (0-359), Saturation (0-255), and Value (0-255) of an object.
Allows or prevents the object from being affected by the fog. Defaults to true.
Determines whether the object is affected by the 2D camera. If set to false, the object will not be affected by the camera regardless of render priority.
Sets the x, y and z-coordinate of the object.
Sets the x-scale of the object.
Sets the x, y and z-scale of the object.
Sets the y-scale of the object.
Sets the z-scale of the object.
Sets the x-coordinate of the object.
Sets the y-coordinate of the object.
Sets the z-coordinate of the object.
Sets whether or not the object uses the Z-buffer.
Allows or prevents the object from writing in the Z-buffer.
Creates a shader object.
Clear the shader of the specified object.
Set float value to the shader..
Set array of values to the shader.
Set shader file.
Set the shader in the shader object to the specified object
Set the technique you want to run.
Set the texture to the shader. You can call multiple textures.
Set vector.
At the specified frame, spawns the added shot object at the source shot object's position.
At the specified frame, spawns the added shot object at the specified distance and angle from the source shot object's position.
Creates a Shot object and returns its ID. In order to draw and fire the shot object and have it listed as an existing bullet, you have to register it using ObjShot_Regist.
Fades out the shot object and deletes it.
Returns the graphic ID of the shot object.
Returns whether the shot object can be deleted by a player bomb. Shot object bomb resistance can be set with ObjShot_SetSpellResist.
Activates the shot object, which will now be fired.
Enables or disables auto-deletion of the shot object when outside of the screen boundaries. Defaults to true.
Sets the damage of the specified shot object. For player shots only.
Delays the shot object, firing it after the specified number of frames. Bullets will glow to announce delay; lasers will be shown very thin.
Deletes the shot object after the specified number of frames.

Enables/disables the ability to erase enemy shots when the specified shot object comes into contact with it. Each time a shot is erased, the penetration of the shot object will go down by 1. For player shots only.
Gives the shot object the specified graphic.
Creates a hitbox of specified radius for collision detection of the shot object. In order to maintain the hitbox, it must be set every frame. There can be multiple hitboxes set for one shot object.

Creates a hitbox of specified radius for collision detection of the shot object. In order to maintain the hitbox, it must be set every frame. There can be multiple hitboxes set for one shot object. Coordinates of hitbox center are set in relation to the object.
Sets whether collision detection of the shot object will be checked. If set to false, the shot object will have no collision detection.

Creates a line segment hitbox between the specified coordinates for collision detection of the shot object. In order to maintain the hitbox, it must be set every frame. There can be multiple hitboxes set for one shot object.
Sets whether the shot object will turn into an item when deleted. If set to false, the shot object will not turn into an item.
Sets the penetration of the shot object. The shot object can hit enemies as many times as the penetration value before being deleted. For player shots only.
Gives the shot object's delay graphic the specified blend type.
Sets whether or not to use the spell damage factor for the shot object. For player shots only.
When set to true, the shot object will not be deleted by the player's bomb. Defaults to false.
Turns the bullet into an item.
Creates a sound object.
Returns the volume (0-100) of the sound file.
Returns true if the sound file is playing.
Loads the specified sound file.
Plays the sound file associated to the object.
Sets the fade time of the sound object (translation of the fade timing needed).
When set to true, the sound will loop.
Sets the timing of the loop based on the sample count.
Sets the timing of the loop, in seconds.
Sets the pan volume of the sound object (-100-100). 0 is neutral, -100 is left-side only, 100 is right-side only.
When set to true, allows the sound object to be restarted rather than continuing from where it left off.
Specifies whether a sound is a BGM or a sound effect:
Sets the volume of the sound object (0-100).
Stops the sound file associated to the object.
Creates a spell card object.
Invokes the spell card object.
Sets the damage of the spell object.
Determines whether the specified spell objects can delete enemy bullets. Defaults to true.
Sets the hit circle for the spell object.
Sets the hit line for the spell object.

Sets the drawing rectangle for the sprite by mapping the center of the source rectangle to (0, 0). For instance, if the rectangle set with ObjSprite2D_SetSourceRect is (24, 32, 48, 46) (which is 24 wide and 14 high), the destination rectangle becomes (-12, -7, 12, 7).
Sets the drawing rectangle for the sprite. This is the rectangle where the sprite will be drawn.
Sets the texture rectangle for the sprite. This is the rectangle on the original texture from which the sprite will be drawn.
If set to true, the object will always be facing the camera.
Sets the drawing rectangle for the sprite. This is the rectangle where the sprite will be drawn.
Sets the texture rectangle for the sprite, and maps the center of the rectangle to the destination coordinates (0, 0).
Sets the texture rectangle for the sprite.
Adds a vertex to the specified object. The amount of rectangles drawn is increased by 1.
Clears vertex count for the specified object.
Adds the last vertex to the object. Transforming the object with ObjRender_* will affect all rectangles after using this function.

Sets the drawing rectangle for the sprite by mapping the center of the source rectangle to (0, 0). For instance, if the rectangle set with ObjSpriteList2D_SetSourceRect is (24, 32, 48, 46) (which is 24 wide and 14 high), the destination rectangle becomes (-12, -7, 12, 7).
Sets the drawing rectangle for the sprite. This is the rectangle where the sprite will be drawn.
Sets the texture rectangle for the sprite. This is the rectangle on the original texture from which the sprite will be drawn.
Returns the angle at which the straight laser object is pointing (different from movement angle).
Sets the angle at which the straight laser object will point at (different from movement angle).
Sets whether the light source at the base of the straight laser object is drawn.
Creates a Text object and returns its ID.
Returns the length of the specified text object. When using Japanese characters, a half-width character counts as 1 and a full-width character counts as 2 characters.
Returns the length of the specified text object. Newlines and ruby text are not counted. When using Japanese characters, both half-width and full-width characters count as 1 character.

Returns an array of the lengths of each line of the specified text object. Newlines and ruby text are not counted. When using Japanese characters, both half-width and full-width characters count as 1 character.
Returns the combined height of all lines of the text object.
Returns the overall width of all lines of the text object.
When true, sets the center of the text object as its transformation center. Default is true.
If set to true, the text will be displayed in bold characters.
Sets the color of the border (0-255).
Sets the type of the font border.
Sets the width of the font border.
Sets the bottom color of the text (0-255).
Sets the top color of the text (0-255).
Sets the size of the font for the text object.
Sets the specified font to the text object.
Sets the line pitch (space between lines) of the text object.
Sets the maximum height of the text object. Any part of the text exceeding this height will not be drawn.
Sets the maximum width of the text object. The text will automatically create a new line whenever needed.
Sets the side pitch (space between characters) of the text object.
Allows or prevents checking for the existence of bracket tags (such as line break or ruby text) within the text for this object.
Gives the text object some text to display.
Sets the given coordinates of the text object as its transformation center (rotation, zoom...).
Pauses (or resumes) the stage script.
Plays the specified sound file as a looping BGM. You can be more precise by using decimals (for instance, if you want to loop from 2.5 seconds on, you can type 2.5).
Plays specified sound file as a sound effect.
Returns the product of a base number and exponent. ^ can also be used.
Creates an error box with the specified string. Execution of the script is stopped, closing the script.

Reloads specified shot image file (you can also (re)load a file that has not been loaded by LoadEnemyShotData). missing explanation about calling the function several times (?) Unlike LoadEnemyShotData, this function can load the same file several times.

Reloads the specified item data. Can be called any amount of times, but currently existing IDs will be replaced by new ones of the same value. You do not need to use LoadItemData before using this function.
Same as LoadPlayerShotData, except a file can be loaded several times. Can be used without loading through LoadPlayerShotData first.

Returns the modulo operation (the remainder of a quotient) of two values. Note: remainder or % will always return a value with the same sign as the divisor. For example, -7 % 4 equals 1 and 7 % -4 equals -1.
Removes specified sound file.
Removes specified texture file.
Renders the specified range of invalid render priority drawings to a texture.
Renders the specified object to texture.
A short comment set arbitrarily using SetReplayInfo
The date and time at which the replay was saved
Replay's file path
Average framerate
The (abbreviated) name of the player script used
List of stage indices that the replay used
Whether the stage is finished or not. (the order of the stage indices is from REPLAY_STAGE_INDEX_LIST)
List of score indices at the start of each stage. (the order of the stage indices is from REPLAY_STAGE_INDEX_LIST)
The player's name
Resets both the focus point and the zoom ratio, respectively to the center of the screen and 1.
Returns the value as an integer. Values of 0.5 or greater are rounded up; otherwise they are rounded down.
Converts any real number to an array format.

Returns the value as a string, with some filtering options. The format is presented as a string that determines how many digits will be shown; it can contain any combination of the following three characters: "0", ".", "#". "0" is a slot for a digit. "." represents the decimal place in the string. "#" creates a space in the string. For example, rtos("000.000", 1.23) = "001.230", and rtos("#00", 1.23) = " 01".
Saves everything in the specified common data area to a data file. Returns true if successful and false if the operation failed.
Saves everything in the specified common data area to a data file at the specified path. Returns true if successful and false if the operation failed.
Saves the specified common data area to the replay file. Returns true if successful and false if the operation failed. If this function is called during a replay, Danmakufu will present an error.
Saves rendered texture to file. The image file created by this function can be used immediately after its execution.
Saves rendered texture to file. You have to set the coordinates of the region to capture. The image file created by this function can be used immediately after its execution.
Saves a replay to the specified replay index.
Saves a picture of the game to file. The image file created by this function can be used immediately after its execution.
Saves a picture of the game to file. You have to set the coordinates of the region to capture. The image file created by this function can be used immediately after its execution.
Sets the Z angle of the 2D Camera.
Sets the x-coordinate of the focus point. It is usually the center of the screen.
Sets the y-coordinate of the focus point. It generally is the center of the screen.
Sets the zoom of the camera (centered on the focus point). This value is usually 1.

Sets the magnification of the X axis of the 2D camera (centered on the focus point). For example, if you set this value to 2, the x-axis will be doubled in size. This value is usually 1. If you specify a negative value, the x-axis will be flipped.

Sets the magnification of the Y axis of the 2D camera (centered on the focus point). For example, if you set this value to 2, the y-axis will be doubled in size. This value is usually 1. If you specify a negative value, the y-axis will be flipped.
Maps the given key to the given value in the specified area in common data. The value can be returned by using GetAreaCommonData with the corresponding area and key.
Sets whether to delete all existing objects that were created in the script at its termination. If set to true, the script's objects will be deleted. The default value is false.
Sets the azimuth angle from the focus point.
Sets the elevation angle from the focus point.
Sets the x-coordinate of the camera focus.
Sets the x-, y-, and z-coordinates of the camera focus.
Sets the y-coordinate of the camera focus.
Sets the z-coordinate of the camera focus.
Objects that are further or nearer than the clipping distance will not be drawn. Default near clipping distance is 10. Default far clipping distance is 2000.
Sets the vertical Pitch angle of the camera.
Sets the distance of the camera to the focus point.
Sets the rotational Roll angle of the camera.
Sets the horizontal Yaw angle of the camera.
Maps the given key to the given value in common data. Uses the default common data area. The value can be returned by using GetCommonData with the corresponding key.
Sets whether or not to create the default autocollected bullet delete items when bullets are deleted to items. True will create the items, false will not. The default value is true.
Defines the script that should be executed when the full game finishes.
Enables or disables fog.
Sets the fog parameters. Starting and ending points are distances from player. To turn the screen dark around the player, you can use SetFogParam(250, 700, 0, 0, 0).
When set to true, the player cannot use normal shots.
When set to true, the player cannot use bombs.
Sets invalid render priority. Drawing within the specified range is disabled by this function.
Sets the render priority for items. Priority must be within the range 0 to 100 (default is 60).
Defines a script to be executed when the game is paused.
Sets the y-coordinate of the auto collect line. A negative value removes the line. Default is no line.
Sets the area within which the player can move.
Sets the amount of frames that will wait before respawning the player.
Sets the amount of frames for player invincibility.
Sets value as life points for the player (can be non integer).
Sets the amount of power points (can be non integer).
Sets the amount of frames the player can counter bomb. Default is 15.
Sets the amount of counter bomb frames the player loses per counter bomb. Default value is 3.
Sets the normal speed and focus speed of the player.
Sets the amount of bombs available for the player (can be non integer).
Sets the replay information. Curently only to be used with REPLAY_COMMENT.
Defines the script that should be executed when the player chooses to save a replay of the game.
Before starting the given script with StartScript, sets a value that is to be passed to the given script upon starting. You can then get this value in the script with GetScriptArgument.
Sets the result of the event in @Event, which can then be retrieved by GetScriptResult.

Sets at what point the bullet will be automatically deleted when leaving the STG screen. Default boundary value is 64. To override this auto deletion, use ObjShot_SetAutoDelete on the bullet you want to prevent from auto deleting.

Sets whether the bullet deletion event is allowed to occur. Event types are: EV_DELETE_SHOT_IMMEDIATE: event will delete the shot immediately EV_DELETE_SHOT_FADE: event will fade out the shot Default is false for both event types.
Saves a replay to the specified replay index.
Creates the specified circle that will check for collisions. The player dies when touching/entering the circle.
Creates the specified line that will check for collisions. The player dies when touching the line.
Sets the render priority for bullets. Priority must be within the range 0 to 100 (default is 50).
Specifies the key to use for fast playback mode. The default key is KEY_LCONTROL. Specify KEY_INVALID if you do not wish to enable fast playback.
Defines the index of the stage to be started next. The value does not need to be sequential.
Defines the stage to be started next.
Defines the player script to be used in the stage.

Can only be called after InitializeStageScene. When this is called, the stage script will be run through once with the replay controlling things such as player movement. You don't have to start from the very first stage, and you can start from the middle of a stage.(unsure)
Sets the STG space frame. Default values are (32, 16, 416, 464, 20, 80).

Sets the given virtual key to the given state. The virtual key will be restored to its true state a frame after you stop calling this function. Keep in mind that if you set it to KEY_HOLD it will not go to KEY_PULL or KEY_PUSH.
Returns the sine of the angle. Sine is a value between -1 and 1 that corresponds to the y-value in a coordinate plane.

Cuts out a specific portion of an array. Array[starting..ending] can also be used. Returns the indices in between the cutoff values (this includes the starting cutoff index but not the ending cutoff index).
Returns an array containing the split strings. For example, SplitString("A/123/BCD", "/") will return ["A", "123", "BCD"].
Ended prematurely
Stage was cleared
Ran out of lives
Whether the stage is finished or not
Starts the script for processing user-defined items.
Starts the specified script (@Initialize is called and @MainLoop begins).
Starts a shot script.
Creates a pseudo slow effect by forcing Danmakufu to run at the specified FPS value (0-60). There is currently only one target available, TARGET_ALL. Use StopSlow to stop this effect.
Starts the stage.
After being killed, before reappearing
The amount of remaining lives has become 0 (game over)
The player has been hit
The player is alive
Removes the pseudo slow, and restores Danmakufu to normal FPS.
Stops specified sound file.
Returns the difference of two values.
Returns the tangent of the angle. Tangent is the slope of the line created by the angle (x/y).
Exits out of the currently running stage.
Returns the value as a string, able to be used by text functions. (Text functions cannot normally read numbers.)
Returns the string with spaces removed from the beginning and ending of the text. For example, TrimString(" ABC ") will return "ABC".
Returns the value with no decimal places. For instance, 1.123 becomes 1. The shortened name trunc can also be used to refer to this function.
All scripts
Package scripts
Player scripts
Plural scripts
Single scripts
Stage scripts
Move down
Move left
Move right
Move up
User key 1
User key 2

Returns the value as a string, with some more filtering options. First, the number of digits on each side of the decimal are specified (000.00 is 3.2 in the format string). Unused digits will be filled with spaces. If preceded by a "-", the digits will be right-justified, adding blank spaces to the right instead of the left. If preceded by a "0", all digits not occupied by the value will be filled by zeroes. If ended with a "d", the value will be presented as an integer. If ended with an "f", the value will be presented as a real number. If ended with an "s", this indicates the value given was in the form of a string. For example, vtos("03d", 1.23) = "001", vtos("3d", 1.23) = " 1", vtos("-3d", 1.23) = "1 ;", vtos("03.5f", 1.23) = "001.23000"
Outputs the given string to log.
